awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantum Transport in Self-Assembled Hybrid Superlattices
awd_abstract_narration:
New phenomena emerge when two semiconductors are brought together in a periodic structure. Such semiconducting superlattices have properties not observed in bulk semiconductor crystals. Their unique properties have led to novel devices such as tunable optical filters, infrared photodetectors, and quantum cascade lasers. Superlattices are expensive to make, requiring ultrahigh vacuum and meticulous layer by layer assembly. The PIs aim to discover a new type of superlattice based on hybrid perovskites, materials with both organic and inorganic components. Hybrid perovskites can be solution processed, allowing for spontaneous assembly into layered nanostructures. Their chemical diversity can revolutionize superlattice research with a vastly expanded range of materials with varied properties. This research will enable future superlattice devices that are scalable and cost-effective. This project will also provide interdisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students, providing them with critical-thinking and problem-solving skills needed for CAREERs in STEM and industry.

Semiconducting superlattices are quantum heterostructures important to condensed matter physics and with applications in advanced electronic technologies. The constituents of the superlattices to date have been limited to inorganic semiconductors, such as GaAs and AlGaAs. This project will investigate quantum transport in a new class of semiconducting superlattices based on Ruddlesden-Popper halide perovskites. The project will employ theoretical and experimental studies in an iterative manner so as to accelerate materials discovery. First principle density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be used to predict materials structures and the optical and electronic properties will be modeled by combining tight-binding models with the DFT calculations. Superlattice structures will be prepared by solution processing and self-assembly, allowing for facile tuning of the electronic structure by varying constituents. The design strategy, using semiconducting organic ligands, will create new possibilities for band engineering. Electrooptical measurements will be used to identify signatures of semiconducting superlattices such as electronic minibands. Complementary electrical characterization will be used to search for evidence of quantum transport, using optical excitation to generate charge carriers without unintended effects arising from doping. The project will elucidate the properties of 2D perovskite superlattices, differentiate their behaviors from conventional inorganic superlattices, and determine if their optical and electronic properties can be tailored in a controllable manner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Semiconducting superlattice is a class of artificial materials that has led to remarkable advancement in both solid-state physics and advanced electronic technology. Recent development of this field, however, has been largely inhibited by the time-consuming, infrastructure-demanding procedure for assembling the artificial structures with nanometer-scale precision. The goal of the proposed research is to discover a new type of superlattices that is not subject to such restriction. The targeted candidate is Ruddlesden-Popper hybrid perovskites that can be self-assembled using facile wet-chemistry synthesis. The PIs aim to address three fundamental questions: (i) do the perovskites behave electronically as superlattices, (ii) how they are differentiated from conventional inorganic semiconducting superlattices, and (iii) whether and how their physical properties can be tailored in a controllable manner.

 

Through the course of this award, the project was able to establish the synthesis and fabrication of a series of organic-inorganic hybrid quantum wells under mild conditions. For example, the team synthesized and characterized thickness tunable hybrid quantum well via tuning the conjugation length of the organic semiconductor and the inorganic slab thickness to realize full tuning of the energy level alignment between the organic and inorganic building blocks.  In addition, the team also discovered the growth of 1D nanowire using 2D perovskite materials and observed efficient waveguide and lasing from these nanostructured perovskite quantum well materials. Furthermore, the team reported fabrication of thin film light-emitting diodes using these hybrid materials and achieved external quantum efficiency over 25%. Thus, this project has established a clear path by which to launch a new avenue of research in this emerging subfield of perovskite semiconductor quantum wells, and it has provided an infrastructure that could reasonably launch translational of these materials to market in the not-too-distant future as well.

 

In addition to the outcomes associated with laboratory work, this project was instrumental in advancing key educational programs as well. For example, the graduate students supported by this project has published several high-impact scientific papers. They gained significant scientific training and are prepared for their independent career. One has obtained his PhD and joined Yale University as a postdoctoral fellow for further training and preparation for his own academic career. The other student published a paper in the prestigious journal Science in her second year of PhD and she plans to pursue an academic career in the US as well. This award has led to the direct training of several undergraduate and visiting undergraduate students as well. During this time, the students have been trained on experimental techniques that have improved their organic chemistry, solid state chemistry, device fabrication, and device physics knowledge to a significant degree. Moreover, they have been able to interact with mentors such that they have a better feel for how this work fits into their future career plans as the undergraduate student aims to go to graduate school. Through all of these efforts, we believe that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.
